bibl.title: Petitioner v. Defendant. Type of document

org.orgName: United States District Court, Western District of Washington, Northern Division

div1.p: (Copy)
IN THE DISTRICT COURT OF THE UNITED STATES FOR THE DISTRICT OF OREGON Washington Northern Division
In the Matter of the Application of YUT YOW Harry Gong for a Writ of Habeas Corpus for Yut Yow ) Petition for a Writ of Habeas Corpus.
To the Hon. R. S. Bean, Judge of the Above entitled court.
The petition of Yut Yow Harry Gong respectfully represents and shows unto your Honor as follows:
I.

That the petitioner is next friend of Yut Yow a native born citizen of the United States of Chinese parentage and was born in the city and County of San Francisco, in the State of California in the year 1869, and is now of the age of 45 years and ever since said time has been and is now a citizen, resident and inhabitant of the United States and that the parents of petitioner were at the time petitioner was born as aforesaid domociled residents of said City of San Francisco, State of California.
II.

That petitioner said Yut Yow is imprisoned, detained, confined and restrained of her liberty by R. P. Bonham, Acting Chinese Inspector John H. Sargeant, Assistant Commissioner in Charge of the Department of Commerce and Labor of the United States at the city of Portland, in the county of Multnomah, State of Oregon Seattle, Washington and within the jurisdiction of the above entitled court. That said imprisonment and restraint is not by virtue of any process issued by a court of the United States or by a judge or commissioner thereof, in a case where such court, judge, or commissioner have acquired exclusive jurisdiction under the laws of the United States, and that such imprisonment and restraint is not by virtue of any judgement or decree of conpetent tribunal of civil or criminal jurisdiction, nor by virtue of any execution issued under such judgement or decree. That the cause or 1.
or pretense of such imprisonment and restraint according to the best knowledge and belief of your petitioner is as follows:

III. That petitioner said Yut Yow is imprisoned under a pretended warrant alleged to have been issued by the Secretary of Commerce and Labor of the United States, which said pretended warrant commands the said R. P. Bonham or other officer of the United States Immigration Service at Portland, Oregon, to deport said petitioner to the Empire of China. That said imprisonment, detention, confinement and restraint is unlawful and illegal and the said pretended warrant of deportation and proceedings thereunder and unlawful and illegal in this, to-wit: That your petitioner was arrested and confined in jail at the City of Portland, Multnomah County, State of Oregon, at the instance and request, and under the direction of the United States Chinese Inspector in Charge at Portland, Oregon, on November 4, 1913, without a warrant or other authority having been granted by any court of said City, County or State, and without any authority of law therefor, and that at said time said United States Chinese Inspector, a pretended statement, which said pretended statement was afterwards reduced to typewriting, a copy of which is annexed hereto, marked "Exhibit A" and made a part of this petition. That said pretended statement was not voluntarily made by petitioner and was obtained from petitioner by duress and petitioner was not informed at said time that any statement made by her would or could be used against her in the proceedings which resulted as herein stated in issuing the pretended warrant of deportation as aforesaid.
IV. That said pretended statement contains among other things the following:questions and answer:

admit "Q. It is true that you have been a prostitute for some 2.
years in this city?
A. Yes.
Q. For how many years?
A. 15 years."

Deny and petitioner alleges that she did not make the above answers to the questions above set forth in the pretended statement. Petitioner alleges that she stated at said time that she had never been a prostitute in said City of Portland but that she had resided in said City for 15 years.

V. Your petitioner further alleges that based upon said pretended statement the Chinese Inspector in Charge at Portland, Oregon, thereafter and on or about November 6, 1913, applied for a warrant of arrest for your petitioner to the Secretary of Commerce and Labor of the United States and on said date, to-wit, November 6, 1913, based upon said pretended statement that said Secretary of Commerce and Labor issued a pretended telegraphic warrant charging petitioner with being an alien and a prostitute at the time of her alleged entry into the United States and that petitioner entered the United States for the purpose of prostitution, or their immoral purpose, and that petitioner had been found practicing prostitution subsequent to her alleged entry into the United States and that she was unlawfully within the United States in that petitioner had been found employed by, in or in connection with a house of prostitution or resort habitually frequented by prostitutes, or where prostitutes gather, and that petitioner had been found an inmate of a house of prostitution.

p.add: Don't except that Deny that statement was a pretended statement

div1.p: VI. DenyThat thereafter and on November 11, 1913, pursuant to said pretended telegraphic warrant the Chinese Inspector in Charge at Portland, Oregon, proceeded to conduct an alleged hearing upon the charges contained in said alleged warrant an dcertain pretended testimony was on said date secured ex parte from petitioenr and two Police Officers of the City of Portland, Oregon, a copy of which said pretended testimony is attached hereto, marked "Exhibit B" and made a part of this petition.
VII. Your petitioner alleges that she had no opportunity to be present when the said pretended tesimony of said Police Officers was taken and had no notice of the time and place of taking the same.

VIII. That after the taking of said pretended testimony said United States Immigration Inspector in Charge at Portland, Oregon, marked "Exhibit A" and "Exhibit B" respectively, to the Secretary of Commerce and Labor of the United States at Washington, D. C. together with an unfavorable report to your petitioner and thereupon said pretended warrant or order of deportation was made by said Secretary of Commerce and Labor and based solely upon said pretended testimony adjudgin your petitioner guilty of said charge and ordering her deported to China. Your petitioner alleges that she has been deprived of a full and fair hearing upon said charge and upon her right to be and remain the United States by reason of the taking of the pretended testimony and proceedings on November 4, 1913, at the Police Station as hereinbefore set forth, and that the taking of said testimony by the Chinese Inspector in Charge at Portland, Oregon and the consideration of said testimony by the Secretary of Commerce and Labor of the United States was unjust, illegal and arbitrary and constitutes an abuse of discretion and power vested in said Chinese Inspector in Charge and said Secretary of Commerce and Labor. The said consideration of such testimony deprived petitioner of a full and fair hearing within the meaning of the Immigration Laws and Rules and Regulations pretaining thereto, and your petitioner has thereby been deprived of her liberty without due process of Law.

IX. Your petitioner further alleges that she has also been deprived of a full and fair hearing upon said charge and upon her right to be and remain in the United States by reason of the refusal of the United States Chinese Inspector in Charge at Portland, Oregon, on 4.
November 11, 1913, to give petitioner a reasonable time from said date petitioner was examined in order to secure witnesses as to her nativity in the United States in the City of San Francisco, State of California.

X. Your petitioner further alleges that said imprisonment, detention, confinement and restraint is also unlawful and illegal in this, that subsequent to peitioner's arrest as aforesaid and prior to the date of said pretended warrant of deportation, and on to-wit, November 21, 1913, she was lawfully married at the City of Portland, Multnomah County, State of Oregon, to a native born citizen of the United States, and petitioner alleges that said Secretary of Commerce and Labor had due notice and knowledge of petitioner's marraige as aforesaid prior to the issuance of said alleged warrant of deportation, and petitioner alleges that by virtue of said marriage petitioner takes the status of her said husband and is a citizen of the United States. And petitioner alleges that by reason fo said marriage said pretended warrant of deportation is null and void. That said illegality of said imprisonment has not been adjudged upon a prior Writ of Habeas Corpus.

WHEREFORE, your petitioner prays that a Writ of Habeas Corpus issue directed to said R. P. Bonham, United States Acting Chinese Inspector in Charge, commanding him to have the body of the said Yut Yow before your Honor at a time and place therein to be specified, to do and receive what shall then and there be considered by your Honor concerning her, the said Yut Yow, together with the time and cause of her detention, and the said Writ and that petitioner be admitted to bail in a reasonable sum until further order of this court.
div1.ab: George S Vaudenrig Attorney for Petitioner.
div1.p: UNITED STATES OF AMERICA DISTRICT OF OREGON Washington Northern Division ) ss.

I, Yut Yow Harry Gong, being first and duly sworn depose and say: That I am the petitioner named in the foregoing petition, that I have read said petition and know the contents thereof and the same are true as I verily believe.
Subscribed and sworn to before me this 11th day of January, 1914.
div1.ab: Ed M Lakin Notary Public for Oregon Deputy Clerk, U.S. Dist. Court, Western Dist. of Washingt
div1.p: UNITED STATES OF AMERICA DISTRICT OF OREGON Washington Northern Division
I, W. W. Banks G S Vaudenrig, do hereby certify that I am petitioner's attorney, that the above and foregoing petition is well founded in law.
div1.ab: G S Vaudenrig Attorney for Petitioner.
